description: From Middle English rinsen, rensen, rencen (“to rinse”), from Old French rincier, reinser, Old Northern French raïncer (“to rinse, cleanse”). Of contested origin. Possibly from Old Norse hreinsa, from Proto-Germanic *hrainisōną (“to clean, purify”), from Proto-Indo-European *krey- (“to separate, divide”). Alternatively from a dissimilation of Old French recincier, from Latin recentare (“to make fresh”).

Cognate with French rincer. From the Germanic verb are Danish rense, Norwegian rense, Swedish rensa (all “to clean”), Old High German reinisōn (“to clean, purify, atone”). It is related with German rein (“pure”), Gothic 𐌷𐍂𐌰𐌹𐌽𐍃 (hrains, “clean”), and English riddle. The Latin verb is related to recent.

examples: I'll just give this knife a quick rinse.

entries.meaning: A liquid used to rinse, now particularly a hair dye.
examples: I had a henna rinse yesterday.

verbs.description: rinse (third-person singular simple present rinses, present participle rinsing, simple past and past participle rinsed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To wash (something) quickly using water and no soap.
examples: You'd better rinse that stain before putting the shirt in the washing machine.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To remove soap from (something) using water.
examples: Rinse the dishes after you wash them.

entries.meaning: (UK, slang) To thoroughly defeat in an argument, fight or other competition.
